question: Are you getting enough sleep? And do you have a regular sleep schedule?
How's your sleep? Are you getting enough sleep?

1.label: eat
notes: original_question: What are your eating habits like, and do you have your meals on schedule?
original_resp: I don't usually have my meals on time
original_question: What are your eating habits like, and do you have your meals on schedule?
original_resp: I don't usually have my meals on time

followup_resp: My work schedule is quite unpredicatable which often causes me to miss my meals or have them at odd hours. Addtionally, I sometimes get so engrossed in my work that I forget to eat. This irrefgular eating pattern has started to affect my health.

followup_resp_1: rv_validation: VALIDATION: It makes sense that an unpredictable work schedule and getting engrossed in work would lead you to miss meals or eat at odd hours. Noticing that this irregular eating pattern has started to affect your health is important, and it is good that you are paying attention to it.

To make this easier within your reality, you could try:
- Set 2-3 simple alarms or calendar nudges (e.g., mid-morning, mid-afternoon, early evening) so you do not forget to eat.
- Keep quick, balanced options at arm’s reach: nuts, yogurt, fruit, cheese, hummus with crackers, pre-made wraps, or protein bars, so you are not skipping entirely.
- Anchor food to existing work cues: eat a snack right before a meeting, or have lunch right after a daily check-in.
- Aim for a minimum baseline on hectic days: at least 2 meals and 1 snack, plus water.
- Prep grab-and-go items once or twice a week so you can eat even when work is hectic.
- If possible, block a 10-15 minute protected break on your calendar as a non-negotiable refuel window.

Since you mentioned your health is being affected, consider checking in with a healthcare professional to make sure your energy, digestion, or blood sugar are on track.

Would you like help creating a simple plan for a typical unpredictable day, including what to keep on hand and when to set reminders?

CBT_statement: rv_validation: VALIDATION: It makes sense that an unpredictable work schedule and getting engrossed in work would lead you to miss meals or eat at odd hours. Noticing that this irregular eating pattern has started to affect your health is important, and it is good that you are paying attention to it.

To make this easier within your reality, you could try:
- Set 2-3 simple alarms or calendar nudges (e.g., mid-morning, mid-afternoon, early evening) so you do not forget to eat.
- Keep quick, balanced options at arm’s reach: nuts, yogurt, fruit, cheese, hummus with crackers, pre-made wraps, or protein bars, so you are not skipping entirely.
- Anchor food to existing work cues: eat a snack right before a meeting, or have lunch right after a daily check-in.
- Aim for a minimum baseline on hectic days: at least 2 meals and 1 snack, plus water.
- Prep grab-and-go items once or twice a week so you can eat even when work is hectic.
- If possible, block a 10-15 minute protected break on your calendar as a non-negotiable refuel window.

Since you mentioned your health is being affected, consider checking in with a healthcare professional to make sure your energy, digestion, or blood sugar are on track.

Would you like help creating a simple plan for a typical unpredictable day, including what to keep on hand and when to set reminders?
CBT_unhelpful_thoughts: I cannot manage my meal time because I think my work is more important than my health.
CBT_challenge: I may not perform well at work if my health deteriorates due to irregular eating habits.
CBT_reframe: My health is critical for me to perform at my best in all areas of life, including my work. I need to figure out some ways I can balance my work and eating habits.
1.name: Maintaining Regular Schedule for Eating
question: How's your eating? Are you eating regularly?
How's your eating habits? Do you have your meals on time?
